keyTakeAways: Cold water does not increase hair shine; warm water is preferable to avoid scalp scalding and hair dehydration.
Split ends cannot be repaired—only cut off with a haircut; products that temporarily mask split ends are not a permanent solution.
Hair growth speed cannot be increased by cutting hair or using products; this is a myth.
Regular washing is essential to prevent scalp buildup, dandruff, and yeast growth; skipping washes can worsen scalp conditions.
Dry shampoo is safe when used sparingly (once between washes), but overuse leads to oil buildup, yeast growth, and itchy flaky scalp.
Sulfate-free shampoos may be better for dry hair as they preserve natural oils, while stronger cleansers may help oily hair.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article debunks four common haircare myths, including the idea that cold water increases shine, split ends can be repaired, hair growth is accelerated by cutting, and that hair can 'self-clean' without washing. Experts Eva Proudman and Tracey Walker from UK Hair Consultants and Hair and Scalp Clinic explain that split ends cannot be mended and must be trimmed, that cold water does not enhance shine, and that regular washing is essential to prevent scalp infections and dandruff. Professor Laura Waters of the University of Huddersfield adds that sulfate-free shampoos are better for dry hair, while dry shampoo should be used sparingly to avoid oil buildup and yeast growth. The key message is that healthy hair comes from simple, science-based practices rather than expensive products or trends.
title: Can shampoo repair hair? Four haircare myths get the chop
